overview_of_class: This course will explore the relationship between religious faith and service. Religious communities have a long-standing practice of providing for the poor, the hungry, the sick, the homeless, those with disabilities and so on. There are faith-based efforts to build peace, seek social justice, defend human rights and serve the common good. Religious institutions have created and supported hospitals, schools and facilities to care for children and the elderly. Whether undertaken by individuals or groups, all these efforts seem to spring from religious commitments and they endeavor to make a difference in the public sphere. Religion motivates many people to do good, even when doing good requires personal sacrifice.

overview_of_class: From Facebook and Twitter to YouTube, Snapchat, Instagram, and Tumblr, this course examines the ways that we can study and learn from social media spaces. We will consider how digital platforms shape the creation and presentation of content, along with the information sharing practices that develop across different online environments. We will also consider what it means to "learn" through social media, and the ways we decide what information to trust when we are exposed to a variety of digital sources in our everyday lives.  The use of multimedia tools and remix culture in particular will be addressed, and how old and new media forms are being fused together to share knowledge in innovative ways.

overview_of_class:
This course examines the role social enterprise plays in our society, the design and purpose of
social enterprises, and the impact social enterprise can have to address social issues and produce social benefit. Participants in this course will have an opportunity to study and examine the social enterprises they participate in, as well as the variety of social enterprises that are supported by Northwestern University. One outcome of the course is to apply understandings and insights gained through this study of social enterprises.
Our fundamental question is: how do we organize as a society to solve social problems?
